A 'vacuum fluorescent display (VFD)' is a display device used commonly on consumer-
electronics equipment such as video cassette recorders, car radios, and
microwave ovens. Invented in Japan in 1967, the displays became common on
calculators and other consumer electronics devices. Joseph A. Castellano
(ed), Handbook of display technology Gulf Professional Publishing, 1992 ISBN
0-12-163420-5 page 9 Unlike liquid crystal displays, a VFD emits a very
bright light with high contrast and can support display elements of various
colours. VFDs can display seven-segment numerals, multi-segment alpha-numeric
characters or can be made in a dot-matrix to display different alphanumeric
characters and symbols. In practice, there is little limit to the shape of the
image that can be displayed: it depends solely on the shape of phosphor on the
anode(s). Hundreds of millions of units are made yearly. Joseph A.
Castellano (ed), Handbook of display technology Gulf Professional Publishing,
1992 ISBN 0-12-163420-5 page 176
